author: @emin86
text: A little late but: For straight lane marker detection, you can filter the lines according to perspective. Look for a line on the left side of the screen with a specific positive m (slope, going up from left to right) and on the right side of the screen look for a line with a negative m (slope, going down from left to right). The m can be in ranges. This way the lane detection has to be started on a lane between lines and would fail if you start it next to the road.

author: @shimuk8
text: Hey Harrison !! I think i have a better approach for the line detection ( even though it's too late I was busy watching your neural network videos :'D ) Instead of using edge detectors and drawing lines for the whole screen.. why don't you just put a ROI in the left side of the scooter approx. x - 300 y - 200 ( first coordinate ) and over there drawing a small rectangle ROI just to detect if the middle yellow road marker is going left or right. It will keep the vehicle close to the yellow line and in the middle of the road also and it's a little easy i guess. I am actually implementing this on a rather similar gta 5 like game watch dogs 2.  But anyway, I gotta say you just made my entire summer vacation just too awesome !! Learned basics, cv2, ML and now this !! Thank you soo much, from India !!!! :')

author: @pranshurokz
text: @sentdex for the final two lines...why don't you just take into account the distance between the two lines to deal with the case where both the lines are on the same side . you can keep a minimum distance value between the two lines , while comparing slopes, to avoid same lane being the the two lines

author: @calder-ty
text: Great Series Harrison! I know you're past this, but another idea for a (in my opinion) simpler rule for staying within the lane is to have scooter try to maximize the distance from both lines. If there is only one, it will try to move away from it and find the other. if they are both there then the middle will maximize the distance between both.
